title: COVID-19 and Your Health
description: Symptoms, testing, what to do if sick, daily activities, and more.
sitename: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
cleaned_text: CDC recommends universal indoor masking for all teachers, staff, students, and visitors to K-12 schools, regardless of vaccination status. Children should return to full-time in-person learning in the fall with layered prevention strategies in place. [here.](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html) [here](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel/index.html). What to Do If You Were Exposed to COVID-19 If you have tested positive or are showing symptoms of COVID-19, [isolate immediately](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/isolation.html). About Being Exposed to COVID-19 A tool to help you determine if you need to isolate or take other steps to prevent spreading COVID-19. If you were exposed to the virus that causes COVID-19 or have been told by a healthcare provider or public health authority that you were exposed, here are the steps that you should take, regardless of your vaccination status or if you have had a previous infection. Learn how COVID-19 spreads and the [factors that make risk of spread higher or lower](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/risks-exposure.html). Wear a [mask](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/masks.html) as soon as you find out you were exposed Start counting from Day 1 - Day 0 is the day of your last exposure to someone with COVID-19 - Day 1 is the first full day after your last exposure Wear a high-quality [mask](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/masks.html) or respirator (e.g., N95) any time you are around others inside your home or indoors in public [1](#footnote) - Do not go places where you are unable to wear a mask. For travel guidance, see CDC's [Travel](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/index.html#can-i-travel)webpage. Take [extra precautions](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/prevention.html) if you will be around people who are [more likely to get very sick from COVID-19](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/risks-getting-very-sick.html). - fever (100.4°F or greater) - cough - shortness of breath [other COVID-19 symptoms](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html) If you develop symptoms [isolate immediately](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/isolation.html) [get tested](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/testing.html) - stay home until you know the result If your test result is positive, follow the [isolation recommendations](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/isolation.html). Test even if you don't develop symptoms. If you already had COVID-19 within the past 90 days, see [specific testing recommendations](/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/testing.html#choosing-a-test). Continue taking precautions through day 10 - Wear a high-quality mask when around others at home and indoors in public You can still develop COVID-19 up to 10 days after you have been exposed. *About negative test results As noted in the Food and Drug Administration labeling for authorized over-the-counter antigen tests, negative test results do not rule out SARS-CoV-2 infection and should not be used as the sole basis for treatment or patient management decisions, including infection control decisions. [1Masks are not recommended for children under ages 2 years and younger, or for people with some disabilities. Other prevention actions (such as improving ventilation) should be used to avoid transmission during these 10 days.] Search for and find historical COVID-19 pages and files.
